text: Early detection Blood Hypertension and chronic Kidney disease What is Blood Hypertension? Blood Hypertension is the Hypertension of the Blood in the arteries as it is pumped around the body by the Heart. Blood Hypertension does not stay the same all the time. It changes to meet the demands of your body. It is usually at its highest when we exercise and lowest when we sleep. It can also rise due to anxiety, excitement, activity or nervousness. How is Blood Hypertension measured? Blood Hypertension is usually measured by wrapping an inflatable Hypertension cuff around the upper arm. Blood Hypertension is recorded as two numbers, for example 140/90 mmHg. The larger number indicates the Hypertension in the arteries as the Heart squeezes out Blood during each beat. This is called the systolic Blood Hypertension. The lower number indicates the Hypertension as the Heart relaxes before the next beat. This is called the diastolic Blood Hypertension.
